comments.content:
external route (BGP, EIGRP and OSPF type 1/2).
Because you are redistributing from EIGRP you are matching the external EIGRP routes.

If you are redistributing ospf to another routing protocol you are gonna match the external OSPF networks (E1 and E2)

discussion.content:
Answer is C.
Lab it, basically when you are doing the redistribution of eigrp inside ospf you are specifing which EIGRP route to inject specifying the match route type external you are saying do not inject eigrp external routes into ospf

A: OSPF external route
B: OSPF external route

C: Matches any external route

D: IS-IS external route

We want to match an EIGRP external router with the deny statement in the route-map. Only answer makes sense is C.

comments.content:
R1
show ip route

D 172.16.2.0/30 [90/307200] via 172.16.250.2, 00:11:36, Ethernet0/0
D 172.16.2.16/31 [90/435200] via 172.16.250.2, 00:11:36, Ethernet0/0
D 172.16.2.32/31 [90/332800] via 172.16.250.2, 00:11:36, Ethernet0/0
D EX 172.16.2.48/28
 [170/2560051456] via 172.16.250.2, 00:11:36, Ethernet0/0
D EX 172.16.2.48/31
 [170/2560025856] via 172.16.250.2, 00:11:36, Etherne

Now R1 has to deny external routes, D EX, when redistributing into OSPF, matching on external type-1 or type-2 does not work as these are for OSPF routes. That rules out A and B. Answer D is for IS-IS redistribution.

discussion.content: Just labbed it, and it is C, the reason being all networks in EIGRP are being advertised with a network statement except for the 172.16.2.48 network. Both R4 and R2 are advertising this network, as R4 is doing a static redistribution. So even R2 has 2 routes to the 172.16.2.48 network, one through its loopback, and one through R4, bboth in the routing table. The only external route in R1 is the 172.16.2.48 route.

Selected Answer: C
C is corerct

Selected Answer: C
Type 1 and 2 with ospf

Selected Answer: C
I decided to lab this question and Im going with C.
I was typing the command and external option will be the most appropiate (by selecting this we are choosing all the external routes).

R7(config-route-map)#match route-type external ?
 external external route (BGP, EIGRP and OSPF type 1/2)
 internal internal route (including OSPF intra/inter area)
 level-1 IS-IS level-1 route
 level-2 IS-IS level-2 route
 local locally generated route
 nssa-external nssa-external route (OSPF type 1/2)
 type-1 OSPF external type 1 route
 type-2 OSPF external type 2 route
 <cr>

comments.content: To add, this question is of bad quality as it is not actually solving the issue correctly. Ideally you just not redistribute any static route into OSPF, as this seems the only one being redistributed. Also if you want to do something with matching ONE route, you can better match on the actual network using "match ip address ..."

discussion.content:

agree with C

Should be C . External type 1 & 2 are for OSPF
R5(config)#router eigrp 1
R5(config-router)#redistribute ospf 1 match ?
 external Redistribute OSPF external routes
 internal Redistribute OSPF internal routes
 nssa-external Redistribute OSPF NSSA external routes

Selected Answer: C
I pick C
Because the figure clearly tells 172.16.2.48/28 are outside EIGRP routes, unless its' wrong.
The type-1 and type-2 in A & B mean OSPF external type 1 and external type 2.

Selected Answer: C
After investigating a little bit more Im going with C. I have found this article that actually agrees with Pietjeplukgeluk. Any value greater than 15 will be considered infinite.

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/ip/enhanced-interior-gateway-routing-protocol-eigrp/8606-redist.html

Selected Answer: C
C seems correct as 16 will be "unreachable", we should reduce hop count to allow adjacent router to keep hop-count below 16==unreachable

The exhibit shows 
R2:
router rip
redistribute ospf 1 metric 15

On R3 we see the R1 connected link 192.168.250.0 [120/15]
So we need to reduce the metric to 14, by the time it reaches R3 the metric will be 15. Mac metric rip = 16.
R3 is getting the R1 connected link through R2 redsitribution, presumably theres a ,link problem between R3 and R1.
Answer = C.

comments.content:
update: There is no like problem between R3 and R1. R2 did redistribution first, that's why there's no route.

Answer = C. Redistribute metric 14, it stays as metric 14 when arriving on R3 (I labbed it) and it gets metric 15 when arriving on R4.

The metric on R3 = 15.
When R2 and R1 redistributed with metric 15, the metric stayed as 15 when going to R3. It was 16 when arrived at R4. Max metric is 16. Therefore R4 has no ip route, and traceroute fails. When redistributing with metric 14, the route gets advertised as metric 14 to R3. Advertised as 15 to R4.

We see one route to the 192.168.56.16 network on R3, the route points to the neighbor that did the ospf to rip redistribution first.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
C is corerct

Selected Answer: A
If you see the metric in R3 it is [110/15], in R4 you do not get the route, in my opinion, C is wrong because if the metric is configured in 15 reducing it to 14 will not help to deliver the route.

comments.content: we are redistributing with metric 15 currently. On next hop router it is metric 15 on R3. On R4 it gets metric 16 and poisoned out - max metric = 16. So we need to redistribute metric 14, it reaches ER3 with metric 14. The reason why the metric didn't increase from R1 to R3 is because R1 is advertising the route, it didn't originate the route.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
A works for me in a lab

Selected Answer: C
My choice is C:
"RIP uses the hop count as a routing metric. RIP prevents routing loops by implementing a limit on the number of hops allowed in a path from the source to a destination. The maximum number of hops allowed for RIP is 15. This hop limit, however, also limits the size of networks that RIP can support."

https://community.cisco.com/t5/networking-knowledge-base/ripv2-routing-information-protocol/ta-p/3117425

R-WEST#config t
R-WEST(config)#archive
R-WEST(Config-archive)#log config
R-WEST (config-archive-log-cfg)#logging enable
R-WEST (config-archive-log-cfg)#hidekeys
R-WEST (config-archive-log-cfg)#notify syslog
R-WEST(config-archive-log-cfg)#exit
R-WEST (config)#snmp-server enable traps
R-WEST (config)#snmp-server enable traps ospf cisco-specific Isa

R-WEST#config t

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. A network administrator configured NetFlow data but the data is not visible at the NetFlow collector. Which configuration allows the router to send the records?

choices.A: Configure a different interface to send the records.
choices.D: Rectify NetFlow collector reachability from the management interface.
choices.C: Configure the NetFlow collector to listen at export-protocol netflow-v5.
choices.B: Configure the management interface in the global routing table to send the records.

comments.content:
k so what we did , changed the MGMT interface to a non used interface g0/0/5 and put it under the MGMT vrf , then we sourced from that for Netflow instead if using G0

Do you have no spare interfaces left at all to try that ? if not im not too sure what option you have left need to check a few things see if theres a way around that

discussion.content:
Hi

had this issue before , its not supported under any MGMT port in ios-xe releases, to source netflow from you will need to use a different interface
https://community.cisco.com/t5/network-management/no-netflow-export-on-management-interface-gig0-of-isr-4431/td-p/2992691
